My claim is that science fiction is an infinite activity, that there is no end to it. It can go on for ever and ever. technique as a rule Even with with the hard science fiction based on something key with planet There are still two ways to go at it. My more usual one is to start with the oddball planet. I see an article in Sky and Telescope about a peculiar star, and I read it up, and then I start figuring, well, how far out would a planet have to be from this star to have an average Earth temperature? And what peculiarities would the star produce if it were that far out? How can I complicate the issue by tilting the axis or making the orbit a little bit eccentric? I have a great deal of fun with my HP 25 at that point. I'll have a lot more when the 97 comes. The alternative, which I am not so good at doing, but which is perfectly kosher for playing the game, is to decide what sort of environment you want for your story. Well, this happens and some people can get away with it. I lack the gall or self-confidence, whichever you want to call it, to feel sure that I'm one of them. I have told my wife if she wants to go to her sister's in the Bahamas for spring vacation, she may go and take our daughter with her. I'm not going. I'm staying home with the typewriter. whether two and a half weeks spring vacation will really produce the rest of the book is a wide open question but at least i keep getting more ideas and writing them down so maybe something can happen this spring i hope so i'd like to get it off my conscience so i can feel i can do something else never never when I've written the typed out the final draft what I've told myself firmly is the final draft I can just barely bring myself to read it there's some sort of acute postpartum depression there and uh when it comes out as a book i feel even worse i know there are things i should have done otherwise takes several years usually before i can read the book of any sort of comfort yes we got a question well if that's it that's it what time is it anyway okay .

There are still two ways to go at it. My more usual one is to start with the oddball planet.
I see an article in Sky and Telescope about a peculiar star, and I read it up, and then I start
figuring, well, how far out would a planet have to be from this star to have an average Earth
temperature? And what peculiarities would the star produce if it were that far out?
How can I complicate the issue by tilting the axis or making the orbit a little bit eccentric?
